sen.j: 黒木 為楨（くろき ためもと、天保15年3月16日 (旧暦)（1844年5月3日） - 大正12年（1923年）2月3日）は、日本の大日本帝国陸軍軍人。
sen.e: Tamemoto KUROKI (May 3, 1844 - February 3, 1923) was a military man of the Imperial Japanese Army (IJA) in Japan.
Tamemoto KUROKI (May 3, 1844 - February 3, 1923) was a military man of the Imperial Japanese Army in Japan.
Tamemoto KUROKI (May 3, 1844 - February 3, 1923) was a military man of the Imperial Japanese Army in Japan.

sen.j: 陸軍大将。
sen.e: He was the army general.
He was the army general.
He was the army general.

sen.j: 仮名 (通称)は七左衛門。
sen.e: His alias (common name) was Shichizaemon
His alias (common name) was Shichizaemon
His alias (common name) was Shichizaemon

sen.j: 妻は中村勝重の次女のヒヤク。
sen.e: His wife was the second daughter of Katsushige NAKAMURA, Hyaku
sen.cmt: ヒヤク→Hyaku 表記はHiyakuですが、発音はHyakuと思われますので、こうしました。
sen.e: His wife was the second daughter of Katsushige NAKAMURA, Hyaku
His wife was the second daughter of Katsushige NAKAMURA, Hyaku

sen.j: 1844年、薩摩藩士帖佐為右衛門の子として薩摩国鹿児島城下加治屋町猫之薬小路（下加治屋町方限）に生まれる。
sen.e: In 1844, he was born in Nekonokusurikoji (猫之薬小路), Kajiya-machi (Hogiri, Shitakajiya-machi), near Kagoshima-jo Castle in Satsuma Province, as the son of a feudal retainer of Satsuma Domain, Tameuemon CHOSA.
sen.cmt: 加治屋町猫之薬小路→正式な読み方が不明です：Nekonokusurikoji (猫之薬小路), Kajiya-machi としました。
sen.e: In 1844, he was born in Nekonokusurikoji (猫之薬小路), Kajiya-machi (Hogiri, Shitakajiya-machi), near Kagoshima-jo Castle in Satsuma Province, as the son of a feudal retainer of Satsuma clan, Tameuemon CHOSA.
sen.cmt: Domain→clan （人の集団の扱い）と修正しました。「加治屋町猫之薬小路」の読み方は確認出来ておりません。
sen.e: In 1844, he was born in Nekonokusurikoji (猫之薬小路), Kajiya-machi (Hogiri, Shitakajiya-machi), near Kagoshima-jo Castle in Satsuma Province, as the son of a feudal retainer of Satsuma clan, Tameuemon CHOSA.

sen.j: のち、黒木万左衛門の養子となり黒木姓を名乗る。
sen.e: Later, he became the adopted son of 黒木万左衛門Manzaemon KUROKI and hand began using the family name Kuroki.
Later, he became the adopted son of 黒木万左衛門 Manzaemon KUROKI, and began using the family name Kuroki.
sen.cmt: スペースを修正し、カンマを補いました。hand を削除しました。「黒木万左衛門」の読み方は確認出来ておりません。
sen.e: Later, he became the adopted son of 黒木万左衛門 Manzaemon KUROKI, and began using the family name Kuroki.

sen.j: 戊辰戦争に従軍。
sen.e: He took a part in the campaign of Boshin War.
He took a part in the campaign of the Boshin War.
He took a part in the campaign of the Boshin War.

sen.j: 鳥羽伏見の戦いでは、薩摩藩の小銃隊を指揮して幕府歩兵を集中射撃により敗走させ、宇都宮城攻防戦では城壁に突進して取り付くなど奮戦し、勝利の契機をつくった。
sen.e: In the Battle of Toba-Fushimi, he lead a small-sized musket unit and forced the foot soldiers of the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) army to withdraw by the barrage of gunfire, and in the Siege of Utsunomiya-jo Castle, he created a momentum to victory, actively fighting by rushing to the castellated walls and cling to it.
sen.cmt: 宇都宮城攻防戦→定訳不明：Siege of Utsunomiya-jo Castleとしました。
sen.e: In the Battle of Toba-Fushimi, he lead a small-sized musket unit and forced the foot soldiers of the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) army to withdraw by the barrage of gunfire, and in the Siege of Utsunomiya-jo Castle, he created momentum to the victory, actively fighting by rushing to the castellated walls and clinging to it.
sen.cmt: スペースを修正しました。the を補いました。a momentum→momentum,cling→clinging と修正しました。
sen.e: In the Battle of Toba-Fushimi, he lead a small-sized musket unit and forced the foot soldiers of the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) army to withdraw by the barrage of gunfire, and in the Siege of Utsunomiya-jo Castle, he created momentum to the victory, actively fighting by rushing to the castellated walls and clinging to it.

sen.j: 1871年、御親兵となって近衛大尉。
sen.e: In 1871, he became a member of Goshimpei (army to convoy the Emperor) and he held the post of Konoe daijo (Senior Lieutenant of Imperial Guard)
sen.cmt: 近衛大尉→定訳不明：Konoe daijo (Senior Lieutenant of Imperial Guard) としました。
sen.e: In 1871, he became a member of Goshimpei (army to convoy the emperor) and he held the post of Konoe taii (Senior Lieutenant of Imperial Guard).
sen.cmt: Emperor→emperor,daijo→taii と修正しました。ピリオドを補いました。「近衛大尉」の定訳は確認出来ておりません。
sen.e: In 1871, he became a member of Goshimpei (army to convoy the emperor) and he held the post of Konoe taii (Senior Lieutenant of Imperial Guard).

sen.j: 西南の役では歩兵第12連隊長として出征し、日清戦争では第6師団 (日本軍)長として威海衛の攻撃に参加する。
sen.e: During the Satsuma Rebellion, he went to the front as the regimental commander of the 12th Regiment of Foot Soldiers, and during the Sino-Japanese War, he participated in the attack to Ikaiei (a harbor city in the Sandong Peninsula, present Weihai in China) as the division commander of the 6th Division (Japanese Army).
sen.cmt: 歩兵第12連隊→定訳不明：the 12th Regiment of Foot Soldiers としました。第6師団 (日本軍)長→定訳不明：division commander of the 6th Division (Japanese Army) としました。威海衛→Ikaiei (a harbor city in the Sandong Peninsula, present Weihai in China) としました。
sen.e: During the Satsuma Rebellion, he went to the front as the regimental commander of the 12th Regiment of Foot Soldiers, and during the Sino-Japanese War, he participated in the attack to Ikaiei (a harbor city in the Sandong Peninsula, present Weihai in China) as the division commander of the 6th Division (Japanese Army).

During the Satsuma Rebellion, he went to the front as the regimental commander of the 12th Regiment of Foot Soldiers, and during the Sino-Japanese War, he participated in the attack to Ikaiei (a harbor city in the Sandong Peninsula, present Weihai in China) as the division commander of the 6th Division (Japanese Army).

sen.j: 戦後、軍功により男爵。
sen.e: After the war, he was conferred the baronage for his military merits.
After the war, he was conferred the baronage for his military merits.
After the war, he was conferred the baronage for his military merits.

sen.j: 1903年、陸軍大将。
sen.e: In 1903, he became the army general.
In 1903, he became the army general.
In 1903, he became the army general.

sen.j: 日露戦争では、第1軍 (日本軍)司令官として鴨緑江から奉天会戦まで連戦し、ロシア軍からは、「クロキンスキー」と恐れられた。
sen.e: During the Russo-Japanese War, he advanced from the Yalu River to the Battle of Mukden fighting various battles along the way as the commander of the First Troop (Japanese Army), and the Russian army was afraid of him, calling him 'Kurokinsky' (after his family name Kuroki).
sen.cmt: 第1軍 (日本軍)司令官→定訳不明：the commander of the First Troop (Japanese army) としました。「クロキンスキー」→定訳不明：'Kurokinsky' (after his family name Kuroki) としました。
sen.e: During the Russo-Japanese War, he advanced from the Yalu River to the Battle of Mukden fighting various battles along the way as the commander of the First Troop (Japanese Army), and the Russian army was afraid of him, calling him 'Kurokinsky' (after his family name Kuroki).

During the Russo-Japanese War, he advanced from the Yalu River to the Battle of Mukden fighting various battles along the way as the commander of the First Troop (Japanese Army), and the Russian army was afraid of him, calling him 'Kurokinsky' (after his family name Kuroki).

sen.j: 戦後、軍功により伯爵。
sen.e: After the war, he was conferred the title of count for his distinguished military service.
After the war, he was conferred the title of count for his distinguished military service.
After the war, he was conferred the title of count for his distinguished military service.

sen.j: 1909年、予備役編入。
sen.e: In 1909, he incorporated into the reserve duty.
In 1909, he incorporated into the reserve duty.
In 1909, he incorporated into the reserve duty.

sen.j: 1917年、枢密顧問官。
sen.e: In 1917, he was appointed the privy councilor
In 1917, he was appointed privy councilor.
sen.cmt: the を削除しました。ピリオドを補いました。
sen.e: In 1917, he was appointed privy councilor.

sen.j: 1923年、2月3日午後10時、肺炎のため東京市青山の自邸において没。
sen.e: On February 3, 1923, at 10:00 p.m., he died of pneumonia at his residence in Aoyama, Tokyo City.
On February 3, 1923, at 10:00 p.m., he died of pneumonia at his residence in Aoyama, Tokyo City.
On February 3, 1923, at 10:00 p.m., he died of pneumonia at his residence in Aoyama, Tokyo City.

sen.j: 享年80（数え）。
sen.e: He was in his 80th year.
sen.cmt: 80（数え）→in his 80th year としました。
sen.e: He was 80 years old (by kazoe: the traditional calculation that makes one one year old at birth).
sen.cmt: （数え）をカッコを使用し修正しました。
sen.e: He was 80 years old (by kazoe: the traditional calculation that makes one one year old at birth).

sen.j: 死後、家督は黒木三次が継承する。
sen.e: After his death, the family reign was took over by Sanji KUROKI.
After his death, the family headship was took over by Sanji KUROKI.
After his death, the family headship was took over by Sanji KUROKI.

sen.j: 三次は帝都復興院参与・貴族院議員を務め正三位勲三等伯爵に昇る。
sen.e: Sanji was raised to the count ranked Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) and decorated the Third Order of Merit, after serving as Sanyo (the councilor) of Teitofukkoin (Council of Imperial Capital Reconstruction) and a member of the House of Peers.
sen.cmt: 帝都復興院→定訳不明： Teitofukkoin (Council of Imperial Capital Reconstruction) としました。
sen.e: Sanji was raised to the count ranked Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) and decorated the Third Order of Merit, after serving as Sanyo (the councilor) of Teito Fukko-in (The Imperial Capital Reconstruction Board) and a member of the House of Peers.
sen.cmt: 「帝都復興院」は"The Imperial Capital Reconstruction Board (Teito Fukko-in)"との表記を確認し、修正しました。
sen.e: Sanji was raised to the count ranked Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) and decorated the Third Order of Merit, after serving as Sanyo (the councilor) of Teito Fukko-in (The Imperial Capital Reconstruction Board) and a member of the House of Peers.

sen.j: 為楨三男の黒田清 (伯爵)は内閣総理大臣黒田清隆陸軍中将伯爵の子、黒田清仲伯爵の養嗣子となり、伯爵の爵位を継ぐ。
sen.e: Tamemoto's third son Kiyoshi KURODA (count) became the adopted heir of Count Kiyonaka KURODA, the son of Lieutenant General (army) and Count Kiyotaka KURODA who was the prime minister.

Tamemoto's third son Kiyoshi KURODA (count) became the adopted heir of Count Kiyonaka KURODA, the son of Lieutenant General (army) and Count Kiyotaka KURODA who was the prime minister, then succeeded the peerage of count.
sen.cmt: 「伯爵の爵位を継ぐ」を補いました。
sen.e: Tamemoto's third son Kiyoshi KURODA (count) became the adopted heir of Count Kiyonaka KURODA, the son of Lieutenant General (army) and Count Kiyotaka KURODA who was the prime minister, then succeeded the peerage of count.

sen.j: 薩摩武士らしい豪傑タイプの猛将で、論理よりも経験を重んじる猪突猛進型の軍人であった。
sen.e: He was a daring and impetuous commander as a typical samurai of Satsuma, and he was also an impulsive military doer, who valued experience more than logic.
He was a daring and impetuous commander as a typical samurai of Satsuma, and he was also an impulsive military person, who valued experience more than logic.
He was a daring and impetuous commander as a typical samurai of Satsuma, and he was also an impulsive military person, who valued experience more than logic.

sen.j: それを証明するかの様に、面白半分に相撲の相手を挑んできた明治天皇を容赦なく投げ飛ばし叩き付けたと云う逸話が残っている。
sen.e: To show his personality, there remains an anecdote, in which he is said to have tumbled Emperor Meiji onto the ground without mercy, when the Emperor playfully challenged him to Sumo.
sen.cmt: 投げ飛ばし叩き付けた→tumbled someone onto the ground としました。
sen.e: To show his personality, there remains an anecdote, in which he is said to have threw the Emperor Meiji onto the ground without mercy, when the Emperor casually challenged him to Sumo.
sen.cmt: tumbled→threw と修正しました。the を補いました。playfully→casually と修正しました。
sen.e: To show his personality, there remains an anecdote, in which he is said to have threw the Emperor Meiji onto the ground without mercy, when the Emperor casually challenged him to Sumo.

sen.j: 野戦指揮官としての長年の経験と勘を生かした優れた采配を見せ、日露開戦直後の日本軍の快進撃は黒木の手腕によるところが大きい。
sen.e: He demonstrated an excellent capacity of waving a baton as a commander in the open battle, making use of his experience for many years and his native intuition, and the Japanese Imperial Army's unexpected run to a victory at the outset in the Russo-Japanese War owed greatly to his ability.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: He demonstrated an excellent capacity of waving a baton as a commander in the open battle, making use of his experience for many years and his native intuition; and, the Japanese Army's unexpected run to a victory at the outset of the Russo-Japanese War owed greatly to his ability.
sen.cmt: （訳文としては既に一つとなっているものが何故か分割されていましたが、原文もこれに合わせて元に戻しました。）また、パンクチュエーションを修正し、適宜修正しました。
sen.e: He demonstrated an excellent capacity of waving a baton as a commander in the open battle, making use of his experience for many years and his native intuition; and, the Japanese Army's unexpected run to a victory at the outset of the Russo-Japanese War owed greatly to his ability.

sen.j: しかし、その猪突猛進型の性格が災いし、総司令部の意思に反した突出を見せる事があり、奉天会戦時には余りの突出ぶりに満州軍総司令部より再三「進撃中止の」命令を出されている。
sen.e: However, he sometimes run out of the General Headquarters' policy owing to his reckless character, and during the Battle of Mukden, the General Headquarters (Japanese Army) in Manchuria repeatedly gave him an order to 'terminate the march' in order to detain his prominent actions.
sen.cmt: 満州軍総司令部→he General Headquarters (Japanese Army) in Manchuria としました。「進撃中止の」命令→an order to 'terminate the march' としました。
sen.e: However, he sometimes run out of the General Headquarters' policy owing to his reckless character, and during the Battle of Mukden, the General Headquarters (Japanese Army) in Manchuria repeatedly gave him an order to 'terminate the march' in order to detain his prominent actions.

However, he sometimes run out of the General Headquarters' policy owing to his reckless character, and during the Battle of Mukden, the General Headquarters (Japanese Army) in Manchuria repeatedly gave him an order to 'terminate the march' in order to detain his prominent actions.

sen.j: 日露戦後は他の軍司令官の大半が元帥 (日本)位に登りつめたが、黒木だけは大将で軍歴を終えている。
sen.e: After the Russo-Japanese War, most of the military commanders were promoted to the post of marshal (Japanese Army), however, he exceptionally ended his career as an army general.
sen.cmt: 日本→Japanese Army としました。
sen.e: After the Russo-Japanese War, most of the military commanders were promoted to the post of marshal (Japanese Army); however, he exceptionally ended his career as an army general.
sen.cmt: パンクチュエーションを修正しました。
sen.e: After the Russo-Japanese War, most of the military commanders were promoted to the post of marshal (Japanese Army); however, he exceptionally ended his career as an army general.

sen.j: 軍歴や功績を考慮すれば元帥に任命されてもおかしくは無い。
sen.e: It was natural that he would have been appointed the marshal for his military career and great achievement.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: It was natural that he would have been appointed the marshal for his military career and great achievement.
It was natural that he would have been appointed the marshal for his military career and great achievement.

sen.j: だが、黒木本人がお飾りだけの名誉職としての元帥位を嫌い、最後まで現場の指揮官としての地位を好んだと云う事もある（同僚に書いた手紙の中に、その様な内容が記されている物が残っている）。
sen.e: However, Kuroki himself disliked the title of marshal, which he considered as a mere painted honorary position, and he was satisfied with the status of a commander in the field until the end of his career (in a letter directed to one of his colleagues, his words of such meaning can be found).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。お飾りだけの名誉職→a mere painted honorary position としました。
sen.e: However, Kuroki himself disliked the title of marshal, which he considered as a mere painted honorary position, and he was satisfied with the status of a commander in the field until the end of his career (In a letter directed to one of his colleagues, his words of such meaning can be found.)
sen.cmt: カッコ内、ピリオドの位置を修正しました。
sen.e: However, Kuroki himself disliked the title of marshal, which he considered as a mere painted honorary position, and he was satisfied with the status of a commander in the field until the end of his career (In a letter directed to one of his colleagues, his words of such meaning can be found.)

sen.j: が、その剛直で荒々しい性格が軍中央で好まれなかったと云うのが理由であるとされている。
sen.e: But besides of this, it is said that the reason came from his rigid and wild character, which was unpopular among the military executives.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。剛直で荒々しい性格→rigid and wild characterとしました。
sen.e: But besides of this, it is said that the reason came from his rigid and wild character, which was unpopular among the military executives.
But besides of this, it is said that the reason came from his rigid and wild character, which was unpopular among the military executives.
